GEOPOLITICAL

Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif stated that after Brussels talks we are on the right track and a lot will depend on what we can do in the next few weeks, while he also stated it is a good start and that political was agreement reached on steps to take. Elsewhere, the Iranian Nuclear Chief stated on state TV the EU should make up for US withdrawal from the deal or else Tehran will enrich uranium “stronger than before”, while the top adviser to Iran’s Supreme leader stated that Tehran will not renegotiate the nuclear deal and will not talk about its missile programme. (Newswires)

US

Fed’s Williams (Voter, Hawkish) said gradual rate rises and 3 or 4 hikes this year are the right direction for policy but also stated he is conscious rates will remain lower versus historical levels. Williams also commented that he is not concerned if inflation overshoots its target by a few tenths and sees wages rising later this year as economy continues to strengthen, while he added that guidance on ‘accommodative’ policy may need to be tweaked at some point. (Newswires)

Fed’s Kaplan (Non-Voter, Neutral) said the US could achieve 3% economic growth but hinges on Labour participation and productivity, while he also stated he is not set on 2 or 3 more hikes this year and is watching the yield curve. (Newswires)

Canadian PM Trudeau said there is an eminently achievable outcome on NAFTA and that “we are very close”. (Newswires)

US Retail Sales MM (Apr) 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.6%, Rev. 0.8%). (Newswires)


MARKET RECAP

Overnight, there was a slight downward bias in US equity futures, following a weak close on Wall Street on Monday, and equity weakness in Asia. Selling was accelerated before the cash equity day got underway, after a retail sales report painted an upbeat picture of the consumer sector; traders subsequently raised bets on four hikes this year, sending US Treasury yields above 3%, helping the dollar bounce, but piling pressure on the US equities complex (though financials held up slightly better than other sectors as yields ticked higher). ES slipped before eventually finding support at/above 2700 in afternoon trade, In stock specifics: Home Depot (HD) reported earnings that beat on the bottom line but missed on the top, and its same store sales were below estimates, with the company citing weather conditions. Agilent Technologies (A) reported numbers in line with expectations, however, the company lowered its current-quarter and full year forecasts, resulting in the stock underperforming the index.
In M&A news, Microchip (MCHP) announced it received antitrust clearance from China, Japan, Austria, Germany and the Philippines for the acquisition of Microsemi (MSCC), but the deal still requires approval from Taiwan Fair Trade Commission. Elsewhere, sources report Qualcomm’s (QCOM) proposed USD 44bln takeover of NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) is still yet to see a solid breakthrough, which is breaking up hopes that the deal would likely see approval at a faster rate. Finally, AT&T’s (T) CEO Stephenson is reported to be ‘ready to close’ the transaction deal with Time Warner (TWX), announcing a final say will be announced on 12 June. SPX -0.71% at 2710, NDX -1.08% at 6888, DJI -0.80% at 24700.

Treasuries were sold in heavy volume on Tuesday amid upbeat retail sales and a slightly more aggressive tone from Fed’s Kaplan and Fed’s Williams, with heavy corporate supply also adding further downward pressure to the complex. The curve bear-steepened with 2yr yields higher by c.3bps and 30yr yields higher by c.7bps. The10yr yield hit the highest level since May 2011 and took out the April 25th high at 3.033%, 2s30s and 2s10s both widened by c.4bps. US 10yr T-Notes futures settled down 20+ ticks lower at 118-19+.

US MARKET WRAP 15 May 2018: Dow snaps winning streak as yields surge higher
content:
•  SNAP-SHOT: Equities down, Treasuries down, DXY up, Crude up
  • * REAR-VIEW: US-China trade tensions, US retail sales upbeat, lots of Fedspeak
  • * AHEAD: Japanese GDP and Australian wages (overnight); on Wednesday, US Industrial Production, EU CPI, ECB's Draghi, Fed's Bullard and Bostic, CSCO earnings

 

* TRADE: NEC Director Kudlow said both the US and China should aim at taking down trade barriers, urging the latter to stop forcing intellectual property and technology transfers. He also noted NAFTA and EU are secondary to China trade disputes. On the China front, Chinese Vice President Wang Qishan said the two should rely on negotiation to solve the existing differences and to increase communication. China on Tuesday told a WTO dispute panel that EU’s accusations of unfair trading by China could equally be applied to EU’s Common Agricultural Policy, or even US corn subsidies. A European Commissioner stated the EU is open for improving the trade relationship with the US, but it is not willing to offer concessions for tariff exemption.

* GEOPOLITICS: Iran Nuclear chief told state TV that the EU should make up for the US withdrawal from the deal, or else Tehran will enrich uranium “stronger than before.” Separately, the Iranian Foreign Minister warned Iran will remain in the nuclear deal if it obtains benefits from it, though wanted to see progress quickly. Elsewhere, the US issued fresh Iran-related sanctions targeted at the Iranian Central chief Sief, and the US Treasury said it is ready to implement further penalties on Russia. On the Korean Peninsula, North Korea suspended high-level talks with South Korea that had been planned for Wednesday in a protest over joint US-South Korean military drills, which it called a 'provocation' amid improved North-South ties.

* NAFTA: Mexico's chief negotiator Smith said there is a 70% chance of landing a NAFTA deal before May 30th; On the flip side, Mexico’s Economy Minister Guajardo does not see a NAFTA deal before Thursday May 17th, the soft deadline set by US House Speaker Ryan. Note, different accounts have reported different versions of the comments from Guajardo, but the official comments appeared to be translated as stated above. Meanwhile, Canada’s PM was confident on the progress of NAFTA, but provided little fresh detail.

*FED SPEAK: Fed’s Kaplan (Non-Voter, Neutral) is not set on two or three more hikes this year, and is watching the yield curve. Kaplan said the US could achieve 3% economic growth but it hinges on labour participation and productivity; Kaplan forecasts US growth to be between 2.50% and 2.75% in 2018, but sees it slowing to 1.75% to 2.0% by 2020 . He sees the neutral rate between 2.5%-3.0%, and again said it is the right thing for Fed to "move towards neutral.” He noted inflation is approaching 2% and is "not running away from us". Finally, he will support Fed's balanced approach to employment and inflation aims. Fed’s Williams (Voter, Hawkish) said `gradual rate rises are in the right direction for policy, but he remains conscious that rates will remain lower versus historical levels. Three or four hikes is in the right ballpark, he said, as he expects the US economy to grow around 2.5% per annum with tailwinds from fiscal stimulus and global growth. He is not ready to declare 'mission accomplished' on inflation, as he wants to see it sustained around the 2% target, but he is not worried if it overshoots its target by a few tenths. He added the economy continues to strengthen, but warned that if the economy underperforms the Fed will go slower. Finally he claimed guidance on ‘accommodative’ policy may need to be tweaked at some point.

*DATA:  US Retail Sales rose by 0.3% in April as expected and were revised higher to 0.8%. Retail sales ex-autos also ticked up and saw an upward revision to the prior data. Overall, because of the revisions, the numbers appear better than expected with analysts at Pantheon seeing these figures adding +0.2% to Q1 GDP. Food and energy sales were partially higher due to sustained prices. Analysts at ING noted that the latest sales data is much clearer as it begins to filter out distortions caused by hurricanes which largely encouraged more spending by forcing consumers to replace their lost items. Nonetheless, ING expects consumer spending to remain sustained amid the economy’s current situation. With higher employment, wages and impetus from the fiscal stimulus, it sees GDP growth at 3%. Business Inventories were left unchanged in March after four consecutive increases following a remarkable rise in sales. The breakdown showed a 0.5% fall in retail stocks offset by a 0.3% increase in manufacturer and wholesaler stocks. Analysts at Oxford Economics expect firms to keep slim inventories throughout 2018 whilst Wells Fargo anticipates inventories to grow again in Q2 and continued investment growth which should encourage firms to fill up inventories.

* EQUITIES: SPX -0.71% at 2710, NDX -1.08% at 6888, DJI -0.80% at 24700.  SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals: -0.74%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: -0.67%, Energy: -0.16%, Financials: -0.63%, Health Care: -1.47%, Industrials: -0.56%, Materials: -0.53%, Technology: -1.31%, Telecoms: -0.99%, Utilities: -1.16%.

* Overnight, there was a slight downward bias in US equity futures, following a weak close on Wall Street on Monday, and equity weakness in Asia. Selling was accelerated before the cash equity day got underway, after a retail sales report painted an upbeat picture of the consumer sector; traders subsequently raised bets on four hikes this year, sending US Treasury yields above 3%, helping the dollar bounce, but piling pressure on the US equities complex (though financials held up slightly better than other sectors as yields ticked higher). ES slipped before eventually finding support at/above 2700 in afternoon trade,

* In stock specifics: Home Depot (HD) reported earnings that beat on the bottom line but missed on the top, and its same store sales were below estimates, with the company citing weather conditions. Agilent Technologies (A) reported numbers in line with expectations, however, the company lowered its current-quarter and full year forecasts, resulting in the stock underperforming the index.

* In M&A news, Microchip (MCHP) announced it received antitrust clearance from China, Japan, Austria, Germany and the Philippines for the acquisition of Microsemi (MSCC), but the deal still requires approval from Taiwan Fair Trade Commission. Elsewhere, sources report Qualcomm’s (QCOM) proposed USD 44bln takeover of NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) is still yet to see a solid breakthrough, which is breaking up hopes that the deal would likely see approval at a faster rate. Finally, AT&T’s (T) CEO Stephenson is reported to be ‘ready to close’ the transaction deal with Time Warner (TWX), announcing a final say will be announced on 12 June.

* CRUDE: WTI futures settle 35 cents higher at USD 71.31/bbl, Brent futures settle 20 cents higher at USD 78.43/bbl. Crude was sold off heavily from near multi-year highs on the back of USD strength (begotten by sharply rising yields), with WTI dropping from just beneath $72 before stabilising beneath $70.40. Brent enjoyed another session of out-performance vs its US counterpart, albeit very slight, underpinned by lingering geopolitical tensions in the Middle East (Iran has again threatened to begin enriching uranium if the JCPOA deal is fully scrapped). Firmer demand conditions are also being cited for some of the gains, after OPEC upgraded its view of global demand growth in its MOMR released on Monday (to +140k BPD) amid a continued decline in OECD commercial stocks. Elsewhere, China refinery throughputs were up by just shy of 12% YY in April to 12.06mln BPD, the second highest on record. Norway raised its 2018 oil price projections by 18% to $64.70 per barrel. Meanwhile, Kazakhstan output between Jan-Apr rose 5.9% YY. After the bell, API reports weekly inventory data, which analysts expect to show a headline draw of 1.5mln barrels, though cushing could see a small build (+65k according to Genscape’s forecast released on Monday), distillates are seen drawing 1.8mln, gasoline is seen drawing by 1.1mln.

* TREASURIES: US 10yr T-Notes futures settled down 20+ ticks lower at 118-19+.

Treasuries were sold in heavy volume on Tuesday amid upbeat retail sales and a slightly more aggressive tone from Fed’s Kaplan and Fed’s Williams, with heavy corporate supply also adding further downward pressure to the complex. The curve bear-steepened with 2yr yields higher by c.3bps and 30yr yields higher by c.7bps. The10yr yield hit the highest level since May 2011 and took out the April 25th high at 3.033%, 2s30s and 2s10s both widened by c.4bps.

* FOREX: USD: The buck reigned supreme on Tuesday, with the dollar hitting fresh YTD highs, largely taking their cue from Treasury yields, which pushed ahead to fresh multi-year highs. The impact of the buck’s strength was particularly evident against EMFX, where the currencies with high external funding requirements were again routed (TRY was whipped again after President Erdogan suggested he would play a more active role in monetary policy should he win re-election); the Argentine ARS was the exception, rising c.3% vs the USD after the central bank sold dollars in spot markets for another day, as well as a NDF operation. The dollar also weighed on gold pushing the precious price below 1300 for the first time since December.   The DXY almost got to 93.500 and the next strong chart resistance around 93.522, which appears almost a formality as the 10 year US yield extends its gains above 3% to fresh multi-year peaks.

EUR, JPY, CHF: the bias was to the downside for the single currency after German GDP and industrial production miss, and an in-line prelim estimate of EZ GDP did nothing to shake the notion that economic momentum in the Eurozone is waning. Couple that with rising US yields helping to widen the differential between US/Germany, and a US retail sales report which saw significant revisions to past data, and EUR sank through support around 1.119, printing lows near 1.1820, before creeping up slightly (but remaining beneath 1.19). The USD strength, underpinned by a steeper Treasury curve helped drive USDJPY above its 200 dma (110.17); though the Swissy couldn’t push on fresh YTD highs, and was relatively unchanged. 

GBP: Sterling couldn’t make any ground against King Dollar after a solid labour market report, which saw the number of jobs added blitz expectations, and earnings ex-bonuses rising. Sterling did manage to make gains against the EUR, however, as traders reasoned that the data may offer the BOE reasons to hike in the coming months (pricing for June remains for unchanged, while August pricing implies an approximately 40% chance of a hike).

CAD, AUD: Doubts that a NAFTA deal could be achieved by Paul Ryan’s soft deadline on 17 May, coupled with a mighty dollar pushed USDCAD to over 1.29, though the air was thin, and the Loonie returned back towards the 1.2850 area. AUD was soft following the RBA’s meeting minutes after the central bank largely reiterated its current guidance. However, there was a slightly dovish twist that seems to be going unreported: the Reserve Bank inserted commentary that “it would be appropriate to hold the cash rate steady and for the Reserve Bank to be a source of stability and confidence,” which some suggest that the RBA is not willing to lift rates until well after the conclusion of the Royal Commission’s look into bank practices – and the new emphasis on lending conditions could suggest that the RBA will potentially be on hold for longer than the market assumes.

* COMING UP: JAPANESE GDP: Growth is expected to have stalled in Q1 after increasing 0.4% in Q4 2017. Capital Economics are even more pessimistic, forecasting growth to actually contract 0.1%, citing a fall in private consumption. “The Bank of Japan’s consumption activity index recorded a 0.4% q/q drop,” the consultancy writes,” a decline in capital goods shipments suggests that nonresidential investment may also have fallen marginally.” However, this data is backward looking and data so far in Q2 has been relatively upbeat, suggesting a return to growth in the quarter.

* COMING UP: EZ CPI: Wednesday sees the final release of the region’s April inflation statistics with Y/Y expected to be revised lower to 1.2% from 1.4% and M/M expected to print at 0.3% vs. March’s 1.0% reading. Although the figures could cause some concern in markets for the ECB’s normalisation efforts, Nordea highlight comments from ECB officials such as ECB’s Praet who “downplayed both the growth and the recent inflation slowdown, stating April’s surprising drop in core inflation reflected the timing of Easter”. As such, the flash print for May at the end of the month will be pivotal in validating or negating the claims made by Praet.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: multiple props propel DXY to fresh 2018 peaks and Dollar pairs through key levels
content:
USD

An array of bullish factors for the Greenback, ranging from latest White House protectionist declarations to rising US Treasury yields, another run on EM currencies/assets, data and more technical moves/positioning. It’s tough to pinpoint the catalyst with any degree of accuracy or certainty, and in truth probably immaterial as momentum built behind the widespread if not universal Buck buying in what increasingly became a self-sustained rally. In short, the index took a while to regain 93.000, but after that the upside progress was relatively rapid to and just over the previous ytd high. The DXY almost got to 93.500 and the next strong chart resistance around 93.522, which appears almost a formality as the 10 year US yield extends its gains above 3% to fresh multi-year peaks.

MAJORS

Losses stretch from circa 0.35% to around 1% for the Dollar’s G10 rivals and a serious of previous 2018 highs/lows and/or significant markers were made in the process. Usd/Chf is back eyeing recent 1.0050+ levels, Usd/Jpy finally took out triple or more tops around 110.00, and the 200 DMA to nudge up towards 110.50, Cable lost 1.3500 (after mixed UK labour/earnings data) and briefly breached its 1.3460 ytd base along with Eur/Usd through 1.1900, 1.1850 and only 20 pips shy of 1.1800 before finding some underlying bids.

NZD/CAD/AUD

No refuge for the Usd’s namesakes in the commodity bloc even though crude prices resisted bearish clutches for a while, as Gold folded (sub-$1300/oz) and risk sentiment soured across the board. The Kiwi lost 0.6900, Loonie weakened through 1.2900 (amidst very mixed messages and views on NAFTA agreement prospects for Thursday, plus weak Canadian existing home prices), and last but by no means least the Aud gave up 0.7500 long before the next big option expiry interest at the strike. Note, some solace for the Nzd may be gleaned from a bounce in GDT auction prices.

EM

New all time lows for many regional currencies and only partial relief with the aid of more direct intervention. Usd/Try climbed above 4.4600 before fading after seemingly outright dovish comments from Turkish PM Erdogan were put into context, while Usd/Rub saw more upside above 62.5000 as a US Treasury official indicated a willingness to impose more sanctions against Russia. Usd/Zar followed the overall trend, but Usd/Ars was capped at 25.0000 again as the authorities offered another Usd5 bn to defend the Peso.

Ely Lilly (LLY) – The pharmaceutical co. announced the Phase 3 trial of galcanezumab, for the treatment of episodic cluster headache, met its primary endpoint whilst Phase 3 study for chronic cluster headache did not meet its primary endpoint. (Newswires)

NASDAQ 100

Alphabet (GOOGL) – An Australian regulator conducted a probe in the co. and found the tech giant collects massive amount of data from Android phones, including detailed location information, with Oracle (ORCL) reporting 1GB of stolen data by the giant from the devices each month. (The Guardian)

Amazon (AMZN) – The retail giant is to launch a fulfilment centre in Ohio which will add 1,500 full-time jobs by the end of 2019. Separately, it is questioning its new operations in Seattle, after construction was halted as the city council voted in favour of a USD 275 per employee tax. Separately, the co. is to open Go stores in San Francisco and Chicago later this year. (Newswires/Recode)

Facebook (FB) – The social media co.’s advertisers appear more worried about the efficiency of their investment rather than over data issues on the platform. Separately, app myPersonality revealed data of 3mln users, as reported by an investigation carried out by New Scientist. (Newswires)

Tesla (TSLA) – The driver involved in the Utah crash reported to be on autopilot mode when she drove into a van. On the incident, CEO Elon Musk tweeted that it is ‘amazing’ the Model S drove into a truck at 60mph, the driver only reported a broken ankle. Separately, Model X was awarded a Guinness World Record after breaking an electric towing record pulling a Boeing’s (BA) 787-9 Dreamliner. OTHER NEWS

content:
• Average cash balance ticks down to 4.9% in May, from 5.0% in April, but still above the 10-year average of 4.5%
  • The Global FMS Macro Indicator* falls for the sixth straight month, sliding into negative territory for the first time since November 2016
  • Expectations for faster global growth continue to fall, with just net 1% of investors indicating they think the global economy will strengthen over the next 12 months; this is the lowest level since February 2016
  • Higher inflation remains the consensus view, with net 79% of investors surveyed expecting core CPI to rise over the next 12 months
  • Only 2% of investors surveyed expect a recession this year; the consensus is for Q1 of 2020, though investors are split between 2019 (41%) and 2020 (43%)
  • Allocation to commodities stays at net 6% overweight, the highest since April 2012 when WTI was $105/bbl
  • The threat of a Fed/ECB hawkish policy mistake (30%) returns to the top of the list of biggest tail risks to the market as trade war concerns (25%) ease; the top three are rounded out by concerns over geopolitics causing oil to reach $100/bbl (12%)
  • “Long FAANG+BAT” remains the most crowded trade for the fourth straight month (29%); “Short US Treasuries” and “Short USD” make up the top three, each at 17%
  • In May, global investors favor banks, tech and energy, while avoiding staples, telecoms and utilities; the relative overweight banks vs. underweight utilities is now an FMS record
  • Allocation to banks rises to net 36% overweight, the second highest level on record
  • In a new survey section on ETFs, 53% of respondents say they actively use ETFs in their portfolio
  • ETF investing remains predominantly an equity-focused activity for fund managers, with 77% of survey participants indicating they use them to gain equity market exposure, as compared to just 8% for corporate bonds and 5% for government bonds

subject: PREVIEW: Fonterra GDT Dairy Auction - futures relatively flat, but upside surprise in store?
content:
The most recent auction saw the headline GDT price index fall 1.1% to USD 3,465, while whole milk powder prices dropped 1.5% to Usd 3,231, confounding indications for a further increase via futures.

WMP futures are steady ahead of today’s auction, suggesting not much deviation in prices from May 1st, but the bias may be skewed towards some payback after declines last time contrary to firmer leads. Given normal margins of error any actual changes may be minimal, but the Kiwi could do with some positive news ahead of NZ wage and PPI data.  

Although there is no set time for the release, results were out around 15.00BST last time, but typically can appear from 14:00BST.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 15th May 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • US Treasury 10-year yield above 3%, dollar stands firmer against its peers
  • Sterling off lows as UK real earnings move back into positive territory
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US retail sales, Fed’s Williams and Kaplan

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were subdued with price relatively range-bound following the modest performance in US, where the major indices finished in the green but well off best levels and the DJIA met resistance just shy of the 25k level but still edged its longest run of gains since September. ASX 200 (-0.6%) was lacklustre with the telecoms sector dragged by weakness in Telstra shares while tech outperforms as Link Administration shares rally on reports the Co. is exploring options with Pexa in which it is the 2nd largest shareholder of. Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) traded lacklustre with focus for individual stocks on corporate earnings, while Shanghai Comp. (+0.6%) and Hang Seng (-1.2%) also lacked impetus despite a firm liquidity operation by the PBoC, with profit taking observed in Hong Kong following the recent streak and as varied tier-1 data from China added to the cautious tone after Industrial Production topped estimates but Retail Sales disappointed. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued following similar trade in T-notes which extended on the prior day’s losses as the US 10yr treasury yield rose back above 3.000%, while a mixed 30-yr JGB auction added to the subdued tone as it showed a decline in accepted prices.

US & China are reportedly closing in on a deal which would give ZTE a reprieve from US sanctions, in exchange for Beijing removing tariffs on billions of US agricultural products, according to people familiar with the matter. In related news, there were also comments from US Ambassador to China Branstad that China and US remain at a far distance on trade and that President Trump wants a dramatic rise in farm exports to China. (Newswires)

PBoC injected CNY 100bln via 7-day and CNY 80bln in 14-day reverse repos for a CNY 180bln daily net injection. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3486 (Prev. 6.3345).

Chinese Industrial Production (Apr) Y/Y 7.0% vs. Exp. 6.4% (Prev. 6.0%); YTD (Apr) 6.9% vs. Exp. 6.7% (Prev. 6.8%). (Newswires)

Chinese Retail Sales (Apr) Y/Y 9.4% vs. Exp. 10.0% (Prev. 10.1%); YTD (Apr) 9.7% vs. Exp. 9.8% (Prev. 9.8%)

Chinese Fixed Assets Ex-Rural YTD (Apr) 7.0% vs. Exp. 7.4% (Prev. 7.5%)

CENTRAL BANKS

Fed nominee Clarida said he fully supports Fed dual mandate and will seek to maintain financial resilience, while he added he will take a balanced approach on reaching Fed targets. (Newswires)

Riksbank's Jochnik said that with inflation stable around 2% it is important to begin lifting rates. Underlying inflation remains weak. He added there is no goal for the SEK, but the recent strengthening has been good. (Newswires)

BoJ Governor Kuroda says there are no plans to move the 10yr yield target for the time being as inflation is still at a distance from 2% target, discussions are being had at board level on side-effects of easy policy, but the removal of the time-frame isn't linked to the debate on impact of easy policy on bank profits. (Newswires)

RBA minutes from the May 1st meeting stated that the board agreed there was not a strong case for near-term policy move and that the next move would likely be a hike rather than a cut. Furthermore, the minutes stated that progress on inflation and unemployment is likely to progress gradually, while it also added that inflation is to remain subdued for some time amid retail competition and slow growth in wages. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

US President Trump and Canadian PM Trudeau discussed via phone call the possibility of a quick NAFTA agreement, in which US President Trump urged for a prompt NAFTA agreement. (Newswires)

UK PM May admitted that the current options regarding UK customs plan are unworkable. This has subsequently increased fears among Eurosceptics that further delays will mean an extension of the 21-month transition period with a Conservative meeting yesterday leading to a clash between PM May and backbencher Rees-Mogg. Further reports suggested that extending the transition arrangement with the EU could be the only way to find a solution to the Irish border issue. (Telegraph/Times/Newswires)

UK Trade Secretary Fox warned of the cost to delays in trade deals. (Times)

UK opposition leader Corbyn has told Labour MPs that a Norway-style option cannot be considered by the party but faces a party divide after rebel Lords passed an amendment to the EU withdrawal bill which would keep membership of the European Economic Area (EEA) as an option. (Guardian)

EU GDP Flash Estimate QQ (Q1) 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 0.4%)

GEOPOLITICAL

Satellite images reportedly showed that North Korea has started to dismantle its Punggye-Ri nuclear test site. There were also reports that 8 South Korean journalists have been invited by North Korea for nuclear site shutdown. (Twitter/38 North)

EQUITIES

European bourses opened on the backfoot but since then are trading mixed (Eurostoxx 50 flat) with the Italy’s FTSE MIB (+0.3%) outperforming its peers with traders watching out for any potential breakthroughs in forming a government. Sectors are also mixed with financials leading the gains while telecom names lag amid downbeat earnings from Vodafone (-3.1%) and Eutelsat (-11.3%). Other individual movers in the wake of earnings include Thyssenkrupp (-4.3%), Iliad (-17.7%), Pandora (-11.7%), easyJet (+2.3%) and Commerzbank (+2.3%).

FX

USD

The Dollar remains on a firmer footing overall after Monday’s late rally that came alongside a rebound in US Treasury yields and has culminated in the 10 year benchmark crossing the 3% threshold again. The index is back above 92.500 within a 92.815-60 range having arrested a relatively pronounced retracement just ahead of 92.200 yesterday. However, retail sales data and more Fed rhetoric could provide further direction and result in another tweak in 2018 rate expectations that have tipped towards 4 hikes for the first time, per CME pricing (and only just at 51%).

JPY

Around 0.25% lower vs the Greenback and mildly underperforming other G10 peers, with Usd/Jpy touching 110.00 again following reports of importer demand during Asia-Pacific trade, but the big figure still proving a formidable barrier to overcome, with recent peaks only a fraction above and the 200 DMA not far away if stops are tripped. Marginally less dovish comments from BoJ Governor Kuroda have also helped to cap the pair.

AUD

The next biggest loser or victim of the Usd revival among majors as the pair retreats to test 0.7500 where more big option expiry interests lie (some 2.6 bn over today and Wednesday). RBA minutes merely reiterating no reason to raise rates anytime soon given slow wage and inflation developments, while risks associated with Aud strength were also highlighted yet again.

GBP

Choppy trade in the run up to UK labour data, with sellers front-running and Cable down to the low 1.3520 area before bouncing towards 1.3550 on an ultimately mixed jobs and earnings report.

EUR/NZD/CHF/CAD

All flat or narrowly mixed vs the Dollar, with the single currency surviving several attempts of 1.1900 on the downside after topping out ahead of 1.2000 on Monday amidst German and Eurozone data misses plus a mixed ZEW survey. The Kiwi is pivoting 0.6900 and deriving a degree of support from the 1.0900 rejection/retreat in Aud/Nzd, ahead of the latest GDT auction, while the Franc is back around parity even though Swiss produce and import prices were considerably higher in April vs the previous month. The Loonie remains off recent peaks around 1.2815 as the countdown to May 17’s ‘soft’ NAFTA deadline continues, but buffered by lofty crude prices.

SEK/NOK/TRY

More upside for the Scandi crowns as Riksbank policy guidance for a hike before year end is underscored and Norwegian GDP surpassed consensus alongside a wider trade surplus, but no respite for the Lira as Turkish PM Erdogan piles more pressure on the CBRT to cut rates.

FIXED INCOME

Near term chart support held in Bunds around the previously flagged 157.94 level, but Gilts are marginally underperforming after a firmer bounce from Liffe lows to trade just above par at 121.82 (+5 ticks vs -19 ticks at one stage). There were some elements of the UK data for bulls/buyers to latch on to (like the bigger than expected claimant count and back month upgrade), but positive impulses from the long-dated syndication are likely to have contributed if not dominated price action. However, the 10 year future is now on the retreat as final issuance details are revealed and the 2071 supply size is set at Gbp6 bn. Elsewhere, USTs remain soft albeit off overnight session lows ahead of retail sales data and latest Fed commentary.

COMMODITIES

Brent is currently trading higher, nearing 3 ½ year highs. The widening spread between the two is stated to be due to geopolitical concerns, as well as an anticipated increase in US June shale production (+145k BPD), that is compounded by record crude production. This leaves the US market well-supplied as the world market is squeezed further by OPEC cuts.

In the metals sector, gold is currently down for the day (-0.3%) at USD 1310.20. Copper has also fallen slightly on increasing stockpiles of the metal. Dalian Iron ore has hit one-month highs on the back of strong Chinese demand.

subject: Price guidance for new 2071 1.625% Gilt set at -0.5bps to flat versus 3.5% 2068 Gilt, according to Bookrunners
UK Rates: more curve steepening ahead of labour data
content: A familiar pattern for Short Sterling futures and Gilts, with the front end anchored/tethered by dovish or on hold BoE policy guidance, while the long end conforms to the broad bearish trend that has re-emerged as US Treasury yields revisit recent peaks. The 3 month strip is settling flat to just a tick up after an early Liffe dip below parity as Gilts probe a bit deeper beneath the 122.00 handle within a 121.58-78 range vs Monday’s 121.77 close. Fundamentally, the domestic spotlight is on labour data that forms the first tier one economic release since last Thursday’s BoE ‘super’ revelations. Consensus for most jobs and the headline wage metric are stronger than previous readings, so confirmation or better will put some tightening premium back on the table of course.

subject: French Presidency adviser says there are no plans to reduce stake in Air France KLM (AF FP), but doesn't mean they will keep this level of stake holding forever
Riksbank's Jochnik says that with inflation stable around 2% it is important to begin lifting rates. Underlying inflation remains weak
reaction_details: - Strength was seen in the SEK following the initial comment that with inflation stable around 2% it is important to begin lifting rates.

8 South Korean journalists have been invited by North Korea for nuclear site shutdown
BoJ's Kuroda says discussions are being had at board level on side-effects of easy policy, but the removal of the time-frame isn't linked to the debate on impact of easy policy on bank profits
Bunds: bears unfazed by German GDP miss
content: Another vain attempt to the upside off the Eurex open, perhaps on a knee-jerk amidst softer than forecast Q1 German GDP data, before sellers pounced to push the 10 year bond just below the 158.00 mark at 157.95. This after an initial 158.13 print and blip to 158.17 vs yesterday’s 158.14 close, as debt markets continue to reverse recent gains and yields rebound off their lows amidst more hawkish vibes from the ECB and Fed via rising 2018 rate hike expectations (odds on 4 tightening moves this year fractionally better then even for the first time). Ahead, ZEW provides a more timely/up to date snapshot of economic sentiment and the outlook ahead of pan Eurozone ip, while the next/nearest downside technical level for Bunds resided just a tick under the current low.

Additional European equity stories post the release of the Daily European equity opening news
content:
Vodafone (VOD LN) – Q1 organic adj. EBITDA +11.8% to EUR 14.7bln vs. Exp. EUR 14.62bln, revenue -2.2% to EUR 46.6bln, due to deconsolidation of Vodafone Netherlands and FX movements, operating profit +15.4% to EUR 4.3bln, final dividend per share of 10.23 Eurocents, +2.0% giving total dividend per share for year of 15.07 Eurocents. Separately, Nick Read is to become CEO on October 1st (Newswires)

Engie (ENGI FP) – Q1 EBITDA 3.2bln +3.0% on reported basis, Q1 revenue EUR 17.5bln up 1.2% on reported basis, confirms earnings guidance for EUR 2.45-2.65bln net recurring income, EBITDA of EUR 9.3-9.7bln, cash dividend of 0.75 EUR/SHR. (Newswires)

easyJet (EZJ LN) – H1 revenue +19.5% to GBP 2.183bln vs. Exp. GBP 2.110bln. Pre-tax loss of GBP 68mln vs. Prev. loss of GBP 236mln. Forward bookings are ahead of last years at 80% for Q3 and 57% H2. Co. says there is a positive trading environment and higher load factors across easyJet routes. (Newswires)

Taylor Wimpey (TW/ LN) – Co. says current market conditions continue to remain stable and in line with trends outlined at annual general meeting in April 2018. Dividend increasing to approximately 7.5% of group net assets vs. Prev. 5%. Co. maintains operating profit margin at circa 21%-22%. 2019 special dividend announced of GBP 350mln. (Newswires)

CYBG (CYBG LN) – Underlying profit before tax +28% YY to GBP 158mln. Statutory loss after tax of GBP 76mln due to PPI legacy costs. Net interest income +4% driven by strong volume and growth and net interest margin of 2.18%. CEO says while economic outlook remains uncertain, CYBG is well positioned to continue executing existing strategy and to capture future growth. (Newswires)

Hargreaves Landsdown (HL/ LN) – YTD new business of GBP 6.6bln net new business in period of GBP 3.3bln, AUM of GBP 88.8bln as of 30th April 2018. (Newswires)

Tod’s (TOD IM) – CEO will soon delegate day to day running of business to his brother, whilst the CEO will retain responsibility of corporate strategies. (Newswires)

 Land securities (LAND LN) – FY revenue profit increased 6.3% to GBP 406mln, adj. diluted earnings per share +9.9% to 53.1 pence, FY loss before tax of GBP 251mln vs. prev. profit of GBP 112mln. (Newswires)

BTG (BTG LN) – FY revenue +9% to GBP 620.5mln, adj. operating profit +18% to GBP 152.7mln, adj. basic EPS +42% to 32.9 pence. (Newswires)

DCC (DCC LN) – FY pretax profit +26.6% to GBP 316.4mln, final dividend +10% to 82.09 pence/shr, adj. continuing operating profit GBP 383.4mln vs. prev. GBP 345mln. (Newswires)

Porsche (PAH3 GY) – Q1 adj. after tax profit EUR 951mln, results form Volkswagen stake fell to EUR 967mln in Q1 vs. prev. EUR 1.01bln, affirms FY guidance. (Newswires)

Aurubis (NDA GY) – Q2 revenue EUR 2.9bln vs. Exp. EUR 3.02bln and pretax EUR 107mln vs. Exp. EUR 107mln. (Newswires)

Iliad (ILD FP) – Q1 consolidated revenue +0.8% YY to over EUR 1.2bln. Mobile service revenues +7%. Deployment of a new sales and marketing approach in the coming weeks to re-boost the group’s growth and accelerate the take-up of ultra-fast landline and mobile offering. Co. says Thomas Reynaud is to become new Co. CEO, Maxime Lombardini to become chairman and Nicolas Jaeger to become CFO. Co. says new governance structure to be effective on May 21st. (Newswires)

Atos (ATO FP) – Co.’s Worldline is to purchase SIX payment services for EUR 2.3bln. (Newswires)

DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
15th May 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were subdued with price relatively range-bound following the modest performance in US, where the major indices finished in the green but well off best levels and the DJIA met resistance just shy of the 25k level but still edged its longest run of gains since September. ASX 200 (-0.4%) was lacklustre with the telecoms sector dragged by weakness in Telstra shares while tech outperforms as Link Administration shares rally on reports the Co. is exploring options with Pexa in which it is the 2nd largest shareholder of. Nikkei 225 (-0.1%) traded lacklustre with focus for individual stocks on corporate earnings, while Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) and Hang Seng (-1.0%) also lacked impetus despite a firm liquidity operation by the PBoC, with profit taking observed in Hong Kong following the recent streak and as varied tier-1 data from China added to the cautious tone after Industrial Production topped estimates but Retail Sales disappointed. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued following similar trade in T-notes which extended on the prior day’s losses as the US 10yr treasury yield rose back above 3.000%, while a mixed 30-yr JGB auction added to the subdued tone as it showed a decline in accepted prices.

FTSE

RBS (RBS LN) – Officials charged with managing the taxpayers’ stake in RBS have been contacting City brokers in order to sell their stakes. (Times)

Centrica (CNA LN) – Co. came under fire as frustrated shareholders demanded answers about the collapse of Co.’s share price. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

British Land (BLND LN) – The co. has launched a formal planning application for a GBP 4bln redevelopment in South East London. (FT)

FirstGroup (FGP LN) – Co. is facing a mounting activist campaign to put itself up for sale following a failed takeover bid from Apollo Global Management. (The Telegraph)

William Hill (WMH LN) – Co. chairman has told ministers that Fixed-Odds Betting Terminals (FOBTs) could leave the co. vulnerable to a takeover bid. (Sky News)

BROKER MOVES

INDIVIOR (INDV LN) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM BUY AT CITI

SAINSBURY (SBRY LN) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL AT EXANE

DAX

RWE (RWE GY) – Q1 adj. net profit -25% at EUR 517mln vs. Exp. EUR 522mln, adj. EBITDA -11.3% at EUR 1.89bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.88bln. Confirms proposition of 0.70 EUR/SHR for 2018 vs. 0.67 EUR/SHR in 2017. Lower profits due to falling wholesale power prices, co. expects adj. EBITDA of EUR 1.4-1.7bln in 2018 excluding Innogy vs. prev. EUR 2.1bln, expects adj. net income of EUR 0.5-0.8bln in 2018 excluding Innogy vs. prev. EUR 1.0bln. (Newswires)

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – Co. is shrinking the Executive Committee of its private and corporate business from 24 to 16 members. (Newswires)

Commerzbank (CBK GY) – Q1 net profit EUR 250mln vs. Exp. EUR 178.3mln. revenue EUR 2.30bln vs. Exp. EUR 2.28bln. Operating profit EUR 289mln vs. Prev. EUR 330mln. Co. says outlook remains unchanged. (Newswires)

Thyssenkrupp (TKA GY) – Q2 revenue -2% at EUR 10.75bln vs. Exp. EUR 10.66bln. Q2 order intake -12% at EUR 10.5bln vs. Exp. EUR 10.8bln. Co. says expects Q3 adj. EBIT expected to be slightly up from prior year’s EUR 519mln. (Newswires)

Allianz (ALV GY) – Q1 revenue EUR 36.5bln vs. Exp. EUR 34.55bln. Net income EUR 1.94bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.77bln. Co. is on track to meet 2018 targets. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Innogy (IGY GY) – Co. has privately told staff of its extreme concern over thousands of job cuts planned as part of a major shakeup of the European energy industry. (The Guardian)

Deutsche Wohnen (DWNI GY) – Q1 FFO I EUR 123.1mln. Co confirms its forecast for FFO I of around EUR 470mln in the base case. (Newswires)

Metro AG (B4B GY) – Q2 revenue -0.8% at EUR 8.45bln vs. Exp. EUR 8.46bln. Q2 EBITDA -36% to EUR 161mln vs. Exp. EUR 183mln. Q2 loss per share at EUR 0.14 vs. Exp. EUR 0.07 share loss. Co. confirms adj. guidance for 2017/18 financial year. CEO said steps have been taken to restore growth in Russia. (Newswires)

Fraport (FRA GY) – Co. says strong growth continues. (Newswires)

Merck (MRK GY) – Q1 adj. EBITDA -18.2% to EUR 1.02bln vs. Exp 1.02bln, revenue EUR 3.69bln vs. Exp. EUR 3.7bln, co. maintains FY moderate organic net sales increase of between 3% and 5% over prev. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

CAC

Renault (RNO FP) - Nissan has contributed EUR 478mln for Q118 to the company’s earnings. (Newswires)

Credit Agricole (ACA FP) – Q1 net income +1.2% to Eur 856mln vs. Exp EUR 878mln, revenue +4.4% to EUR 4.91bln vs. Exp EUR 4.98bln, CET1 ratio at 11.4% vs. prev. 11.7%, medium term target of 11% maintained. Q1 LCL results in line with projection of stable revenues in FY 2018 vs. prev. (Newswires)

AXA (CS FP) – The co. said to have completed an IPO of AXA equitable totalling USD 4.0bln. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Euronext (ENX FP) – Q1 revenue +15.9% to EUR 146.7mln, EBITDA +25.1% to EUR 88.2mln reaching 60.1% margin, Q1 growth in EPS to EUR 0.82, adj. EPS +28.1% at EUR 0.85. (Newswires)

Air France (AF FP) – Co. could appoint board member Anne-Marie Couderc as interim CEO. (Le Figaro)

Faurecia (EO FP) – 2020 targets: sales growth of above 7% per year to exceed EUR 20bln. Operating margin at 8& of sales and net cash flow at 4% of sales. Co. says sales from “new value spaces” for sustainable mobility and “smart life on board” will accelerate from 2020 to reach EUR 6.8bln by 2025. Co. says it will continue strategy aimed at de-risking Co.’s profile and increasing its resilience. (Newswires)

Eutelsat (ETL FP) - 9-mth like-for-like revenue EUR 1.03bln (down 5%) (-7.6% reported), Q3 EUR 337mln vs EUR 364mln a year ago, Q3 backlog orders of EUR 4.6bln (Prev. yr EUR 5.2bln). (Newswires)

Eiffage (FOUG FP) – Q1 Sales EUR 3.4bln (+5.6%, +4.3% like-for-like), Confirms FY18 guidance, Contracting book increased to EUR 14.21bln. (+23% y/y). (Newswires)

JCDecaux (DEC FP) - Q1 adj. revenue declined 2.6% to EUR 742.5mln, organic revenue rises 2.8%. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

PAN EUROPE

EDP (EDP PL) – China Three Gorges made a EUR 9bln offer for the co. as it sensed that other firms were planning a takeover. (Newswires)

Pirelli (PIRC IM) – Q1 revenue EUR 1.310bln vs Exp. EUR 1.315bln, Adj. EBIT before one-offs stood at EUR 229.4mln vs Exp. EUR 224mln, Net debt at end of March EUR 3.94bln vs Exp. EUR 3.98bln. Confirms 2018 profit guidance, and expected 2018 revenues to grow by at least 9%. (Newswires) 

YNAP (YNAP IM) – Q1 Revenue EUR 518mln vs Exp. subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian equity markets were subdued with price relatively range-bound following the modest performance in US. FX markets consolidated throughout most of the Asia-Pac session
content:
Asian equity markets were subdued with prices relatively range-bound following the modest performance in US. FX markets consolidated throughout most of the Asia-Pac session

UK PM May admitted that the current options regarding UK customs plan are unworkable. The League and 5SM in Italy need more time to form a government

Looking ahead, highlights include GE and EZ GDP, UK jobs, German ZEW, US retail sales, Fed’s Williams and Kaplan

ASIA

Asian equity markets were subdued with price relatively range-bound following the modest performance in US, where the major indices finished in the green but well off best levels and the DJIA met resistance just shy of the 25k level but still edged its longest run of gains since September. ASX 200 (-0.4%) was lacklustre with the telecoms sector dragged by weakness in Telstra shares while tech outperforms as Link Administration shares rally on reports the Co. is exploring options with Pexa in which it is the 2nd largest shareholder of. Nikkei 225 (-0.1%) traded lacklustre with focus for individual stocks on corporate earnings, while Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) and Hang Seng (-1.0%) also lacked impetus despite a firm liquidity operation by the PBoC, with profit taking observed in Hong Kong following the recent streak and as varied tier-1 data from China added to the cautious tone after Industrial Production topped estimates but Retail Sales disappointed. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued following similar trade in T-notes which extended on the prior day’s losses as the US 10yr treasury yield rose back above 3.000%, while a mixed 30-yr JGB auction added to the subdued tone as it showed a decline in accepted prices.

US & China are reportedly closing in on a deal which would give ZTE a reprieve from US sanctions, in exchange for Beijing removing tariffs on billions of US agricultural products, according to people familiar with the matter. In related news, there were also comments from US Ambassador to China Branstad that China and US remain at a far distance on trade and that President Trump wants a dramatic rise in farm exports to China. (Newswires)

PBoC injected CNY 100bln via 7-day and CNY 80bln in 14-day reverse repos for a CNY 180bln daily net injection. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3486 (Prev. 6.3345).

Chinese Industrial Production (Apr) Y/Y 7.0% vs. Exp. 6.4% (Prev. 6.0%); YTD (Apr) 6.9% vs. Exp. 6.7% (Prev. 6.8%). (Newswires)
Chinese Retail Sales (Apr) Y/Y 9.4% vs. Exp. 10.0% (Prev. 10.1%); YTD (Apr) 9.7% vs. Exp. 9.8% (Prev. 9.8%)
Chinese Fixed Assets Ex-Rural YTD (Apr) 7.0% vs. Exp. 7.4% (Prev. 7.5%)


UK/EU

UK PM May admitted that the current options regarding UK customs plan are unworkable. This has subsequently increased fears among Eurosceptics that further delays will mean an extension of the 21-month transition period with a Conservative meeting yesterday leading to a clash between PM May and backbencher Rees-Mogg. Further reports suggested that extending the transition arrangement with the EU could be the only way to find a solution to the Irish border issue. (Telegraph/Times/Newswires)
 

UK Trade Secretary Fox warned of the cost to delays in trade deals. (Times)

UK opposition leader Corbyn has told Labour MPs that a Norway-style option cannot be considered by the party, but faces a party divide after rebel Lords passed an amendment to the EU withdrawal bill which would keep membership of the European Economic Area (EEA) as an option. (Guardian)


Incoming ECB member Rehn (Finland) said short term indicators suggest the pace of growth has somewhat cooled in the early months of this year and that this could be temporary, but the data is indicating a slowdown in growth. Rehn also stated that overall economic outlook for euro area is strong although medium term growth is tilted to the downside. (Newswires) Rehn will enter the ECB in July

Italy’s anti-establishment Five Star Movement and the far-right League have pleaded for a “few more days” to seal their alliance to govern the nation. (FT)
 

FX

FX markets consolidated throughout most the session following yesterday’s swings with the USD-index near the prior session’s highs. The predominantly quiet overnight trade in currencies provided brief respite from the pressure in EUR/USD and GBP/USD, although both remained firmly below the 1.2000 and 1.3600 handles respectively and later extended on lows as US yields rose. Elsewhere, JPY was slightly weaker with USD/JPY underpinned by importer demand and on the firmer greenback, while commodity-linked currencies were subdued amid recent losses in the metals complex and with AUD kept lacklustre following an unsurprising RBA minutes release in which the central bank reiterated there wasn’t a strong case for a near-term policy move.

RBA minutes from the May 1st meeting stated that the board agreed there was not a strong case for near-term policy move and that the next move would likely be a hike rather than a cut. Furthermore, the minutes stated that progress on inflation and unemployment is likely to progress gradually, while it also added that inflation is to remain subdued for some time amid retail competition and slow growth in wages. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were subdued overnight with the metals complex pressured by a firmer greenback, which saw further marginal losses to gold prices, while copper also extended on the prior day’s lows amid the cautious risk tone. Elsewhere, oil was flat with WTI crude futures stuck at the USD 71.00/bbl level while Brent held above the USD 78.00bbl with geopolitical concerns cited by some for the widening spread. 

GEOPOLITICS

Satellite images reportedly showed that North Korea has started to dismantle its Punggye-Ri nuclear test site. (Twitter/38 North)
 

US

US President Trump and Canadian PM Trudeau discussed via phone call the possibility of a quick NAFTA agreement, in which US President Trump urged for a prompt NAFTA agreement. (Newswires)

US Commerce Secretary Ross accused China and Europe of being highly protectionist and accused China of stealing intellectual as well as forcing tech transfers. Ross also commented that China hasn’t obliged to rules since joining the WTO and warned that agricultural tariffs will come at China’s cost. Ross further stated the US will be impose EU steel tariffs if no deal is met before June 1st and that key NAFTA topics remain a work in progress. (Newswires)

Fed nominee Clarida said he fully supports Fed dual mandate and will seek to maintain financial resilience, while he added he will take a balanced approach on reaching Fed targets. (Newswires)

PREVIEW: RBA minutes from the May 1st meeting where the central bank kept rates on hold at the record low of 1.50% as expected, due at 0230BST/2030CDT/0930HKT
content:
Today sees the release of the RBA’s minutes from the May 1st meeting where the central bank held the Cash Rate Target at the record low of 1.50%. This was in-line with consensus as ASX 30 Day Interbank Cash Rate Futures had indicated a 100% expectation the central bank would keep policy unchanged.

At the meeting, the RBA reiterated that steady policy is consistent with growth and inflation goals, while it also repeated that a strengthening currency would slow economic pick-up. The central bank also stated that low rates are supporting the domestic economy and that stronger exports are expected, while it added that inflation and wage growth likely to stay low for a while.

As a guide, markets were unreactive to the actual policy announcement and statement considering the decision was as unanimously expected and with statement a rehash of the regular rhetoric from the central bank.
